original_data.question:
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks. During this time he has felt like his eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings and his urine has been frothy. He has hypertension and rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen. He does not smoke. He has a history of chronic alcohol abuse. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, periorbital edema, 2+ pedal edema, and ascites. He has swan-neck deformities and nodules of multiple fingers and swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.2 mg/dl
Prothrombin time 12 seconds
Serum
Albumin 2.8 g/dl
Total bilirubin 1.0 mg/dl
Alkaline phosphatase 120 U/L
AST 20 U/L
ALT 19 U/L
Urea 18 mg/dl
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
Urine
Protein 3+
WBCs 5–10/hpf
RBCs negative
Bacteria negative
Ultrasound of the liver and kidneys shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?"

model_response:
This patient has nephrotic syndrome due to amyloidosis. Renal amyloidosis is a complication of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's clinical picture is consistent with nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, peripheral edema, and hyperlipidemia. The patient's rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis may have contributed to his amyloidosis. The liver and kidneys are the most common sites of amyloid deposition. Amyloid is an abnormal protein that is deposited in various tissues in the body. The AA (amyloid-associated) form of amyloid is associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis. The AL (amyloid light chain) form of amyloid is associated with plasma cell dyscrasias such as multiple myeloma. The diagnosis of amyloidosis is made by biopsy. Amyloid is seen as an amorphous, pink, hyaline material in the tissue with a characteristic apple-green birefringence under polarized light. The prognosis of amyloidosis is poor, with death occurring from complications of nephrotic syndrome or heart failure. The treatment of amyloidosis is directed at the underlying disease. Ibuprofen can cause renal and hepatic disease but not amyloid deposition. Congestive heart failure can cause pedal edema, but would not explain the other findings or the amyloid deposition. Decreased cardiac ejection fraction could cause pedal edema but would not explain the other findings or the amyloid deposition.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
The state of weariness following a period of exertion, mental or physical, characterized by a decreased capacity for work and reduced efficiency to respond to stimuli.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in TISSUES or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the SKIN in SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE.
The inferior part of the lower extremity between the KNEE and the ANKLE.
The distal extremity of the leg in vertebrates, consisting of the tarsus (ANKLE); METATARSUS; phalanges; and the soft tissues surrounding these bones.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The organ of sight constituting a pair of globular organs made up of a three-layered roughly spherical structure specialized for receiving and responding to light.
A rounded, puffy face with fat deposits in the temporal fossa and cheeks, a double chin. [HPO:probinson]
The time period between dawn and noon.
Liquid by-product of excretion produced in the kidneys, temporarily stored in the bladder until discharge through the URETHRA.

Persistently high systemic arterial BLOOD PRESSURE. Based on multiple readings (BLOOD PRESSURE DETERMINATION), hypertension is currently defined as when SYSTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently greater than 140 mm Hg or when DIASTOLIC PRESSURE is consistently 90 mm Hg or more.
Rheumatoid Factor: an immunoglobulin, most often of the IgM class, directed against the host's own immunoglobulin, usually an IgG. It is a non-specific marker and is present in many diseases.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
A long-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It is effective in the treatment of ANGINA PECTORIS and HYPERTENSION.

An antineoplastic antimetabolite with immunosuppressant properties. It is an inhibitor of TETRAHYDROFOLATE DEHYDROGENASE and prevents the formation of tetrahydrofolate, necessary for synthesis of thymidylate, an essential component of DNA.
A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent with analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory properties
Visible gaseous suspension of carbon and other particulate matter emitted from burning substances.
Record and study of past events.

A primary, chronic disease with genetic, psychosocial, and environmental factors influencing its development and manifestations. The disease is often progressive and fatal. It is characterized by impaired control over drinking, preoccupation with the drug alcohol, use of alcohol despite adverse consequences, and distortions in thinking, most notably denial. Each of these symptoms may be continuous or periodic. (Morse & Flavin for the Joint Commission of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence and the American Society of Addiction Medicine to Study the Definition and Criteria for the Diagnosis of Alcoholism: in JAMA 1992;268:1012-4)
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
Swelling due to an excessive accumulation of fluid around the orbits of the face.
An abnormal accumulation of excess fluid in the lower extremity resulting in swelling of the feet and extending upward to the lower leg. [HPO:probinson]
Accumulation or retention of free fluid within the peritoneal cavity.
A small lump, swelling or collection of tissue.
An indefinite large quantity that is considered to be greater than several.
Abnormal fluid accumulation in TISSUES or body cavities. Most cases of edema are present under the SKIN in SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUE.
Anything that limits; a limitation.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
A synovial hinge connection formed between the bones of the FEMUR; TIBIA; and PATELLA.

Clotting time of PLASMA recalcified in the presence of excess TISSUE THROMBOPLASTIN. Factors measured are FIBRINOGEN; PROTHROMBIN; FACTOR V; FACTOR VII; and FACTOR X. It is used for monitoring anticoagulant therapy with COUMARINS.
The determination of the amount of protein present in a urine sample.

The visualization of deep structures of the body by recording the reflections or echoes of ultrasonic pulses directed into the tissues. Use of ultrasound for imaging or diagnostic purposes employs frequencies ranging from 1.6 to 10 megahertz.
A large lobed glandular organ in the abdomen of vertebrates that is responsible for detoxification, metabolism, synthesis and storage of various substances.
Body organ that filters blood for the secretion of URINE and that regulates ion concentrations.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
